item.title: [RESOLVED] CSS Nerd Rage
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:

[code=css]

uberBlog

body {
background-color: #DFD;
font-family: “Trebuchet MS”, sans-serif;
font-size: 12pt;
}

#container_top {
background-image: url(‘images/top.png’);
height: 19px;
width: 607px;
}

#container {
background-image: url(‘images/middle.png’);
padding: 0 10px;
width: 587px;
}

#container_bottom {
background-image: url(‘images/bottom.png’);
height: 19px;
width: 607px;
}

#wrapper {
width: 607px;
margin: auto;
margin-top: 10px;
}

Trollolol

[/code]

That should work, just changed adjustments because it looks like it collapsed the container image.

Read full topic

item.title: [RESOLVED] CSS Nerd Rage
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

tags generally leave automatic whitespace (a new line) on the top and bottom so remove it and just leave the text there and see what you get.

Read full topic

item.title: [RESOLVED] CSS Nerd Rage
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[s]Alright, so I wanted to make a div with rounded corners. To accomplish this I have created three images: one for the top two corners, one to be repeated in the middle with the content, and one with the bottom two corners. Unforunately, this fucks up in IE and Chrome, and I have no idea what I’m doing wrong.

Here is CSS and HTML:

[code=css]

uberBlog

body {
background-color: #DFD;
font-family: “Trebuchet MS”, sans-serif;
font-size: 12pt;
}

#container_top {
background-image: url(‘images/top.png’);
height: 19px;
width: 607px;
}

#container {
background-image: url(‘images/middle.png’);
padding: 0 10px;
width: 587px;
}

#container_bottom {
background-image: url(‘images/bottom.png’);
height: 19px;
width: 607px;
}

#wrapper {
width: 607px;
margin: auto;
margin-top: 10px;
}

Trollolol

[/code]

Help would be greatly appreciated![/s]

Thanks to Saphire and justaguy

Read full topic
